script.text:
I live with two guys, right? And one of them's an asshole because he labels everything that he cooks or buys with his name on it so I don't eat it like this is how you know someone doesn't want to be friends with you when they're labeling their shit all the time."
"Like last week we had our first roommate meeting where we were supposed to talk about boundaries but really what happened was my roommate Brian just yelled at me for eating his hummus."
script.cons: Muddy delivery, Could use more clarity

script.text: "I wasn't even hungry. He brought home this giant container of hummus from Whole Foods, which is disgusting. You can get better stuff at Costco."
script.cons: Overuse, Lack of Emphasis, Unoriginal Setup

script.text: "But apparently it didn't make him feel good enough to go back there, so he bought another tub. Then he wrote HUMMUS IN THE FRIDGE in Sharpie across the top."
script.cons: Muddy transition between setups, Could benefit from more clarity on who Brian is.

script.text: And then he left town before anyone else got home, hoping that no one would find out."
script.cons: Muddled delivery, Could have been more surprising

script.text: So I walk into the apartment after work, see this huge red warning label staring me down. Like, oh shit, who did that? Probably not gonna eat that now."
script.cons: Muddy tone, Could use more clarity.

script.text: (Setup) Now, here's the thing though. We have a very open relationship. If something belongs to somebody specifically, they write their fucking name in big letters across the front."
script.pros: Incongruous tone, sets up conflict between roommates.
script.cons: Muddy transition, unclear purpose of humor.

script.text: (Setup) "If something belongs to everybody, nobody writes anything."
script.pros: Incongruous tone, clever use of language.

script.text:
So if nothing belonged to anybody, why does it say BRIAN'S HUMMUS IN BIG LETTERS ACROSS THE FRONT OF THIS CONTAINER THAT BELONGS TO EVERYBODY?"
"So... It says that because he wants it to belong only to himself."
(Setup) This guy has such a bad case of ownership issues."
(Setup) Well, he gets up real early every morning and goes running around Lake Michigan by himself as well."
(Setup) But anyway, I'm telling people like, hey man, your friend Steve, he should do CrossFit. They'll tell me yeah, dude, he loves doing crossfit. That's why he calls himself meathead."

decisions.reason: The component has set up the scene and introduced the character's situation. It provides background information necessary for understanding the rest of the transcript.

Setup must happen before Incongruity/Punchline/Callback/End. This component sets the scene and establishes the characters involved. It provides background information necessary for the audience to understand the situation being presented.
The component must set up the rest of the joke. It has no other function than to create tension leading to either a punchline, callback, or incongruity.
The component has set up the scene and introduced elements necessary for the rest of the transcript. It establishes the setting and characters involved.
The component must set up the scene and characters for the rest of the transcript. It introduces the concept of roommates and food ownership.

The component must set up the rest of the story by introducing elements such as characters, setting, conflict, or situation. It provides background information necessary for understanding the plot. In this case, it introduces the character of the narrator and her roommates, including Brian, and sets up the scenario involving the hummus.
Setup must happen again to create tension leading to punchline.
Setup must happen again to create tension leading to punchline.
Setup must precede punchline. Incongruity must follow setup. Punchline follows incongruity. Callback follows punchline. End concludes the component.
Setup must establish context for the humor to follow.
